Message.Title: Obama's NSA is collecting phone records of millions daily
Message.Msg: Remember the liberal press including yahoo complaining about government collecting phone records of suspected terrorists during the Bush administration? Now Obama is tapping everybody including conservatives and yahoo just ignores it. (top yahoo homepage headline is about stars shocked about singapore car prices!) story from the nytimes - U.S. Is Secretly Collecting Records of Verizon Calls The Obama administration is secretly carrying out a domestic surveillance program under which it is collecting business communications records involving Americans under a hotly debated section of the Patriot Act, according to a highly classified court order disclosed on Wednesday night. The order, signed by Judge Roger Vinson of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court in April, directs a Verizon Communications subsidiary, Verizon Business Network Services, to turn over “on an ongoing daily basis” to the National Security Agency all call logs “between the United States and abroad” or “wholly within the United States, including local telephone calls.”

Message.Title: Credit Suisse seen poised for leading role in Alibaba IPO
Message.Msg: Credit Suisse is expected to take a leading role in the anticipated IPO of China's Alibaba Group, according to people familiar with the matter, a coveted position that would yield massive fees for the bank as rivals jostle for a role in the offer. Credit Suisse Group AG's transaction history with Alibaba has increased the bank's chances of a key role in any issue, the people familiar with the matter said, adding that Morgan Stanley is also likely to land a top role. Alibaba has yet to shortlist or formally mandate any bank for the IPO, but bankers expect the listing to take place in Hong Kong by the end of this year or early 2014. The issue is expected to value Alibaba at $70-$100 billion, and could raise $15 billion.

Topic.Title: Credit Suisse seen poised for leading role in Alibaba IPO

Message.Msg: As part of last year's share buy-back deal, Yahoo, which now has a 24 percent stake in Alibaba, can appoint one of the joint global coordinators of any eventual IPO. Yahoo can also review and comment on any documents required to carry out an Alibaba offering, according to a U.S. securities filing.

Topic.Title: Credit Suisse seen poised for leading role in Alibaba IPO

Message.Msg: Japanese telecoms and Internet firm SoftBank Corp may also have a similar agreement with the company, given that its 35 percent stake in Alibaba is larger than Yahoo's share. SoftBank, locked in a bidding war with Dish Network Corp for U.S. telecoms firm Sprint Nextel Corp, told banks they could hurt their chances of landing a role in the Alibaba IPO if they help Dish, sources familiar with the situation said. SoftBank did not immediately return a request for comment. Credit Suisse recently dropped out of Dish's financing for Sprint, one person familiar with the matter said.

Message.Title: $100 BILLION IPO Goldman Sachs to lend US$500m to Alibaba ahead of expected IPO
Message.Msg: The New York-based investment bank pledged funds to the facility for China's biggest e-commerce company, proceeds of which would partly be used to refinance debt at a lower cost, the people said on Tuesday, asking not to be identified because the details are private. Alibaba has set tomorrow as response deadline for banks. Alibaba is rolling out a smartphone operating system and buying a stake in the country's biggest Twitter-like service - steps considered a prelude to an initial public offering that may value the company at as much as US$100 billion.

Message.Title: Yahoo Undervalued Based on the Sum of Parts Analysis
Message.Msg: Yahoo owns 24% of Alibaba Group, expected to IPO at $100 Billion. Yahoo! also has $831 million in preferred shares of Alibaba Group equal to $0.75 per share for shareholders. The 35% ownership interest in Yahoo! Japan (YOJ) is worth about $7 per share, and finally, the cash per share is worth $4.87 to Yahoo! shareholders. The total value of the investments and cash is a little over $23.50 per share. At a current price of $25.75 per share, that means investors are paying just over $2.50 for shares of Yahoo!. Yahoo! should generate over $1.5 billion EBITDA in 2014 within its core business. At a multiple of 5x - 6x EBITDA, this is equal to around $6.50 - $8.00 in per share value.

Topic.Title: Yahoo Will Be Bought for Over $40 per Share After Alibaba IPO

Message.Msg: $40 wouldn't do it. Especially after Microsoft offered a 60% premium back in 2008 (and Yahoo STILL said 'no thanks'). Google wouldn't make a run because the government still doesn't want them owning that much search share (they'd have to sell it off to Microsoft). Apple is a software company, not a content company so I don't think they'd be interested. Microsoft wouldn't do it now either because they are about ready to start the process of splitting their company in half. That leaves Yahoo going solo and running with their "mobile first" strategy.....which is why you seeing them buy up lots of mobile talent.
